title.narrative: ICLD- Capacitating Local Leaders in Zimbabwe

description.narrative: Bidraget syftar till att främja kvinnors deltagande i lokalpolitiken för att på lång sikt stärka kapaciteten för lokalt styre.

ICLD has applied to Sida for funding of 11 million SEK to carry out the "Capacitating Local Leaders in Zimbabwe" during the period 2019-2021.
The intervention aims at training 28 plus minus newly elected women councillors, 10 elected male councillors as well as 10 selected Council officials, and 2 officials from Ministry of Local Government Public Works and National Housing (MoLG PW&NH). The ICLD will implement the intervention in partnership with Gender Links, Midlands State University and MoLG PW&NH.
The intervention’s total budget is 11 million SEK, which is wholly supported by the Embassy

The objective of the programme is to promote the involvement of women in local politics in Zimbabwe with the long-term view of strengthening local governance capacity and local democracy. Given this objective, the rationale of the Training Programme Capacitating Local Leaders in Zimbabwe is to focus on local leaders both males and females in Zimbabwe, believing that they have the potential to act as advocates and role models for women who may consider making a career in politics or administration. The expected result by the end of the programme is: Councillors and their partner council managers, women and men, will have increased personal leadership and interpersonal skills and be able to skilfully perform their duties.

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative:
Due to the Covid pandemic, activities of the programme were delayed and ICLD was also forced to adapt the format in which the activities took place. Before the pandemic hit the region, the programme managed to carry out a regional study visit to Kenya for the Cohort 4 participants - with a focus on Devolution. After that, the programme was delayed and trainings were moved to the digital format. Amongst others, a digital and online education tool for learning about Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals was developed.
Cohort 4 of the leadership programme - consisting of 22 senior officials and ward councillors in pairs from the ten provinces of Zimbabwe plus an extra from the Harare region, was successfully completed during 2020. At their final workshop, the participants listed what they found as the most valuable aspects of the programme, which included: networking, learning, exposure (to other councils, countries, ways of working), time management, gender sensitivity and leadership skills, etc. At this event, the participants also presented their action plans, for further implementation. These plans included topics such as: improved living conditions for diasbled youth, waste management, renewable energy, health clinic, youth empowerment, sexual harassment policy, etc.
However, start up of Cohort 5 was postponed, as was the planned alumni reunion.
A very positive step forward when it comes to women's political participation in the country was the Cabinets move towards amending the constitution to also include the 30% gender quota for representation at local decision-making level. This progress can be seen as a result of ICLD's partner organisations work for the quota to materialize also at local government level.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
